Crimes.Application_Facts: Adjani did not declare his son during initial processing or at landing, preventing examination of the child as a non-accompanying family member.
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Compliant with residency obligations but failed disclosure requirement
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Non-disclosure regardless of intent or knowledge
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Examination of non-accompanying family members required at time of sponsor’s application
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over judicial review of IAD decision
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Immigration application forms, sponsorship application, IAD findings
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of declaration of dependent at time of landing
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not applicable – decision based on regulatory compliance, not credibility
Crimes.Outcome: Adjani's son denied permanent residence under family class
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of IAD decision, certification of question
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Overturn of visa officer and IAD decisions
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness of administrative decision; validity of regulation under Charter
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Section 117(9)(d) validly excludes non-disclosed, non-accompanying family members regardless of intent
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration Division, Immigration Appeal Division (IAD), Federal Court

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose dependent upon landing
Crimes.Violation_Type: Omission of dependent in immigration application
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: s. 117(9)(d) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Adjani discovered a son after landing and attempted to sponsor him; the child was not declared during initial processing or landing.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Permanent resident seeking to sponsor a previously undisclosed child
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Sponsor met residency requirements but failed disclosure obligation
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Failure to disclose constitutes regulatory bar, irrespective of intent
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Requirement for examination of dependents at time of sponsor’s application
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court review of administrative immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Landing documents, sponsorship application, IAD record
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No evidence of disclosure at time of entry or application
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not central – issue was legal interpretation and compliance
Crimes.Outcome: Son ineligible for family class sponsorship due to non-disclosure
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review and appeal from IAD decision
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Certification of question and reversal of denial
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of s. 117(9)(d); reasonableness of IAD decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Regulation applies strictly: non-disclosed non-accompanying dependents cannot be sponsored
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer, Immigration Appeal Division (IAD), Federal Court

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status due to domestic violence in Israel but faced credibility issues and insufficient evidence against state protection.
Procedural_Issue: Board's refusal to adjourn the hearing
failed to secure counsel despite opportunities
Evidence_Used: Presumption of state protection in democratic Israel
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence to rebut the presumption of state protection
failed to provide clear evidence of inability to access state protection
Credibility_Assessment: applicant delayed proceedings and failed to secure counsel
Decision_Outcome: Board did not err in refusing the adjournment
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Legal_Standard_Applied: Administrative tribunals have discretion to grant or deny adjournments based on specific factors
state protection is presumed unless claimant provides clear evidence of inability
Decision_Rationale: Applicant delayed proceedings, failed to secure counsel, and provided insufficient evidence to overcome the presumption of state protection in Israel

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical presence and residency centralization requirements
Legal_Provision_Violated: Citizenship Act - 1095 days of residence in Canada over four years
Application_Facts: Respondent was physically present for 567 days and absent for 893 days; Citizenship Judge relied on ties to Canada without sufficient assessment of centralization of mode of living
Residency_Compliance: No - failed to meet 1095-day requirement and insufficient evidence of centralizing life in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship Judge failed to properly apply legal test for residency; decision found unreasonable
Evidence_Used: Physical presence records, ties to Canada (e.g., family, employment, property)
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient analysis of whether respondent centralized mode of living in Canada
Decision_Outcome: Original approval of citizenship application set aside
Outcome: Appeal allowed
Relief_Sought: Review and correction of erroneous citizenship approval
Remedy_Sought: Remand for reconsideration by a different Citizenship Judge
Legal_Standard_Applied: Residency under the Citizenship Act: physical presence or centralization of mode of living
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge's conclusion was not supported by adequate reasoning or proper legal analysis regarding centralization of residence

Crime_Name: Inadmissibility to Canada due to Serious Criminality
Legal_Issue: Whether the IAD breached the rules of natural justice by failing to allow full submissions on the appeal
Decision_Outcome: IAD’s decision set aside, matter referred to a different panel for redetermination

Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, setting aside of IAD decision, redetermination by a new panel
Outcome: Judicial review allowed, decision set aside, redetermination ordered

Dispute_Type: Declaratory relief regarding marital status in immigration context
Legal_Issue: Whether the Federal Court has jurisdiction to declare facts about an applicant's marital status for immigration purposes
Outcome: Claim struck out for lack of jurisdiction
Credibility_Assessment: Plaintiff alleged he answered truthfully; court did not assess credibility due to jurisdictional bar
Basis_of_Claim: Seeking declarations that the plaintiff was never married and provided truthful answers during immigration interview
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Federal Court lacks jurisdiction to make factual declarations on marital status for immigration purposes
Application_Error: Attempting to use Federal Court for declaratory relief on factual marital status
Legal_Standard: Abuse of process; no reasonable cause of action
Application_Factor: Marital status declaration sought for immigration application review
Decision_Outcome: Motion to strike granted; claim dismissed with costs

Dispute_Type: Judicial review of citizenship application decision
Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge erred in applying the physical presence test for residency requirements under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Outcome: Minister's judicial review application granted; Citizenship Judge's decision overturned
Evidence_Type: Record of physical presence days in Canada
Legal_Provision: Paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act requiring 1,095 days of physical presence in Canada within four years prior to application
Basis_of_Claim: Respondent was two days short of the required 1,095-day physical presence period
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Physical presence requirement cannot be waived by Citizenship Judge; no discretion to blend tests or deem shortfall insignificant
Application_Error: Improper blending of residency tests and treating a two-day shortfall as insignificant
Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to Citizenship Judge's interpretation of residency requirements
Legal_Standard: Statutory compliance with 1,095-day physical presence requirement under s. 5(1)(c)
Application_Factor: Number of days physically present in Canada during the four-year period preceding application
Decision_Outcome: Decision set aside; Respondent may reapply if eligible
Authority: Federal Court (implied from judicial review context)
